newsitem.title: USA: Tongass plan reduces allowable timber cut.
newsitem.headline: Tongass plan reduces allowable timber cut.

text.p: Logging in the largest U.S. national forest will be allowed at only half the level of past years under a final 10-year plan issued Friday by the U.S. Forest Service.
The Forest Service's Tongass Land Management Plan called for an average logging cap of 220 million to 267 million board feet a year for the next decade in the Alaskan forest.
That compared to the 450 million board foot annual cap set by the previous 10-year plan.
"It is a balanced plan. I am confident it will sustain all forest resources over the long haul," Alaska Regional Forester Phil Janik said in a teleconferenced news briefing from his Juneau office.

Logging supporters claimed the Tongass National Forest plan will starve the southeast Alaska timber industry. Environmentalists said it neglected fish and wildife protections needed to repair damages of past over-logging.
The head of an Alaska timber industry group disputed Forest Service claims that more logging would damage the Tongass.

"It's all pseudo-science. What they've done is they've beefed up the so-called habitat protections for a problem that doesn't exist. It's to solve a perception that's obviously pervasive along the Potomac and in New York," said Jack Phelps, executive director of the Alaska Forest Association.
His group and two local governments have entered an agreement to appeal the plan and may sue to overturn it.

But Greg Petrich of the Alaska Rainforest Campaign said the new Tongass plan still accomodated high-volume operations, even though both of the regions pulp mills -- fueled by low-priced, contract-supplied timber -- have closed.
With the region's tourism and fishing industries booming, "The trees are worth more standing," he said.

The new Tongass plan calls for increased protection of fish and wildlife, such as 1,000-foot no-logging buffer zones along streams and beaches. It also includes protections for the forest's fragile limestome caves, which hold newly discovered archaelogical and paleontological relics.

Janik said he hoped the environmental protections would make it unnecessary for the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service to list two Tongass subspecies -- the Alexander Archipelago wolf and the Queen Charlotte goshawk -- as threatened.
Alaska's all-Republican congressional delegation -- strong backers of the timber industry -- vowed a review of the plan.

"This huge reduction (in logging) means no real benefit for the animals and plants, but it does mean lost potential for Alaskans who work for a living in the wood products industry," Rep. Don Young, chairman of the House Resources Committee, said in a statement.
But Democratic Gov. Tony Knowles praised the plan as balanced, and said its release would help southeast Alaska communities plan their economic futures.
Tongass is a 17-million acre forest that sprawls over steep mountains, vast glaciers and thousands of thickly wooded islands in southeast Alaska.
